content:
# Claim cases types:

	1.  DLUG01 - Damage luggage claim. 
	Description:  The passenger files this claim when their checked luggage is damaged during the airlines handling, causing harm to the contents or the bag itself. 
	2.  FLDC02 - Flight Delay Controlled.
	Description: The flight was delayed due to the circumstances within the airline's control, the passenger has been informed of the delay less than 12 hours before the departure time on their original ticket, and they have waited at the airport for 4 hours or more after the departure time on your original ticket. 
	Those circumstances (possibleValues) are limited to: 
	Maintenance issues, Crew scheduling problems, Logistical delays, Ground operations
	3. FDFM03 - Flight Delay force majeure.
	Description: a passenger is not entitled to any compensation if the flight was delayed due to the circumstances that are not within the airline's control.
	The list of those circumstances (possibleValues) is limited to:
	a) Weather conditions: severe weather such as thunderstorms, hurricanes, snowstorms, or dense fog can lead to airport closures, air traffic restrictions, and ultimately flight delays.
	b) Security Issues - Unplanned security-related incidents or threats at an airport may lead to temporary closures, resulting in delays for affected flights.
	c) Natural disasters - Events such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, or tsunamis can disrupt air travel infrastructure and lead to flight delays.
	4. CAFL04 - Canceled Flight.
	Description: The flight was cancelled due to the circumstances within the airline's control, the passenger has been informed of the cancelation less than 12 hours before the departure time on their original ticket.



# Mandatory details (slots) to be provided with every claim submitted:
	• s001 - Passenger’s Name (example: Peter White)
	• s002 - Passenger’s phone_number:  (example:  1-800-334-45-02)
	• s003 -  reservation number:  consist of 3 uppercase letters and 3 numbers (example: VGH890)
	• s004 - ticket_number: 11 digit number (example: 14522764111)
	• s005 - airline_name (example: Dream Wings)
	• s006 - flight_numbers:  consist of 2 upper case letter and 3 numbers (example: VC456)
	• s007 - arrival_city (example: Texas)
	• s008 - departure_city (example: Texas)
	• s009 - notification_date: date when the notification about delayed or canceled flight was issued by the airline and/or received by the passenger (applicable only for FLDC02, FDFM03, CAFL04,  “n/a” if for DLUG01). (example: 3:00 pm, 3 hours before the scheduled departure )
	• s010 - notification_time - time when the notification about delayed or canceled flight was issued by the airline and/or received by the passenger (applicable only for FLDC02, FDFM03, CAFL04, “n/a” if for DLUG01). (example: 3:00 pm, 3 hours before the scheduled departure )
	• s011 - delay_period (in hours) (example: 9 hours)
	• s012 - Passenger’s email (example: joe.dow@company.com)
	• s013 - travel_date (example: 01.01.21, 5th of March 2020)
        • s014 - departure_time: the time initially scheduled at the moment of ticket purchase. (example: 4:20 pm)

# Instructions:

You are an internal system that handles customer’s claims. You are provided with the list of some types of claims cases that were submitted by the passengers to airline companies.  There is also a list of important mandatory details (slots) that a customer should include when submitting a claim.

Intents: 
Each intent has a unique ID, associated with it, that consists of four upper case letters, 2 numbers, a name and intent description. It may also include  possibleValues which means the slot must match one of the provided values. Please acquaint yourself with the specific definition of each intent by reading the descriptions associated with each intent and understanding the constraints required for each intent.
Slots: For each intent there are also slots associated with them.  Slots are values that need to be retrieved for a particular intent.  Each slot will have a  unique ID that starts with1 lower case letter followed by 3 numbers,  name and description. It could also include a field exampleValues where examples are given but the extracted slots do not need to exactly match those given values.  

Go through the information available in the customer's claim (the utterance below) and assign the relevant document type. To give the correct answer use the list of the intents (types of claims) provided above. Also extract all relevant slots and their values. If multiple slots are provided, fill all the slots.  If a slot value is not provided, set the value of the slot to "none".
 If some slots that are present in the utterance were not provided, ignore them and do not extract.

Return your answer in json.
The JSON should always have a key “output”. The value of “output” should be a dictionary where the key of this dictionary is the intent id and the values is a sub-dictionary where the keys are the slots associated with the given intent and the values are the slot values. If intent can't be identified, please return: {"prediction_intent": "None"}.
Be sure to extract  and fill the slots in the order they were provided in the list above : from "s001" to "s014".

# Utterance:

Dear SnowStarWings,
I'm writing to file a claim regarding the delay of my flight # BG145 scheduled  for departure from Phoenix on 18.03.21 at 10.00 am. The delay was caused by unprecedented snowstorm that led to the closer of the airport and disrupted normal flight operations. As a result of the bad meteorological conditions my flight was delayed by 11 hours , causing me significant inconvenience .I missed the connecting flight and had to incur additional expenses during the extended delay period. I kindly request compensation or appropriate assistance with accordance with the airline policies.
Sincerely,
Emma Grey,
3-555-555-55-55
